title: Before 1 January 2018, will the Chicago Board Options Exchange's CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) exceed 30?
preds: Since 1990 (when it first came into existence) the VIX has only had 581 trading days with a VIX at 30 or higher. In total there have been 6,970 days since 1990 for the VIX to trade. That is a base rate probability of 8.34% (581/6,970). So, there is an 8.34% probability that the VIX will trade at 30 or higher on a given day. Some more stats, in the last 365 trading days, the VIX has had 0 days at 30 or higher. In the last 730 trading days (2 years), the VIX has had 4 trading days of 30 or higher. Currently the VIX stands at 9.14% at the time of this writing. It's important to note that the VIX has never gone from 9 to 30 over night. It always takes time for the VIX to accelerate. When the VIX was at its most recent 30 reading in August 2015, the VIX trough before the run up to 30 was 13. It took 7 days for the VIX to reach 30 from 13. In the meantime, the S&P 500 dropped 8.6%. Before that, in 2011, the second to last time the VIX went to 30, it took 24 days for the VIX to go from 15 (lowest point before the uptrend) to reach 30. In that time the S&P 500 lost 10.4% in value. Both times the VIX 30 day average before it broker higher was 13.4 (2015) and 19 (2011). Going back further through the data follows similar statistics to 2011 data in terms of length of time to go from a relatively low VIX (e.g. 13) to 30, and the magnitude of the drop in the S&P 500. The only way the vix will go to 30 is if the S&P 500 drops. And usually the S&P 500 must drop pretty significantly approx. 5%+ for the VIX to reach 30. To forecast we must first estimate the probability that the S&P 500 will drop about 5% between now and Jan 1, 2018. There are 38 trading days between now and then. This year has been relatively, and eerily, quiet. To most people that means that a drop is imminent. However, given the strong earnings data, GDP growth, and balance sheets of companies, plus low interest rates and relative ease of capital, my estimate of the likelihood of a large drop due to a surprise is relatively low. Now surprises can come from anywhere, and don't show themselves before they happen (e.g. black swan events). However, I believe more of the same will continue for the S&P 500 through the remainder of the year as investors have generally been sanguine to surprises in the news. Investors have generally been complacent this year given generally strong economic data and the lack of stronger opportunities outside the stock market. Additionally, both December and November have generally been stronger months for the S&P 500 (Yardeni research). The S&P 500, since 1990 has had 6,970 trading days. On average, there is a 23% chance the S&P 500 will drop 50 basis points. And a 12% chance it will drop 1.0%. We have had four 1% or greater drops this year. And these have not pushed the meter much past 16 on the VIX. So given the relative amount of complacency in the market, the short number of days left to trade (38 days), the amount of time and magnitude of a price drop for the VIX to spike from a low of 13 to a high of 30, (lowest 7 days) which requires repeated drops in the S&P 500 to get there, I don't see a high likelihood of a VIX spiking above 30 before Jan 2018. *** UPDATE: We now have 8 trading days left. It is highly unlikely that even if we get a sever drop in the S&P 500 that it would push the vix to 30 over the next 8 days. I give this a 1% probability of happening. ***UPDATE: With just one trading day left, it is impossible. Changing my estimate to 0%.
I want this to be .5 but the going rate is already close to that.
It's a good thing Bitcoin isn't part of this basket.

However, given the strong earnings data, GDP growth, and balance sheets of companies, plus low interest rates and relative ease of capital, my estimate of the likelihood of a large drop due to a surprise is relatively low. http://libertystreeteconomics.newyorkfed.org/2017/11/the-low-volatility-puzzle-are-investors-complacent.html
"however you measure it, stock market volatility is unusually low. As of September 21, the year-to-date standard deviation of S&P 500 daily returns has been 0.45 percent, the lowest level since 1965 on an annual basis. Intraday volatility is also low. As the chart below indicates, estimates of realized volatility are currently around 6 percent in annualized units, near the minimum of the historical distribution. The chart also reports the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index (VIX), a market-based measure of implied volatility over a one-month horizon from forward-looking S&P 500 index option prices. Despite a backdrop with high political uncertainty (for example, as measured by Baker, Bloom, and Davis’s economic policy uncertainty index), the VIX is currently around 9-10 percent after hovering near all-time lows for much of 2017.  The Low Volatility Puzzle: Are Investors Complacent? Common View: Today Is Abnormal and Current Stock Market Volatility Is a Concern 
Aside from the FOMC minutes excerpt above, other commentators (for example, see Jeffrey Frankel’s recent blog post) have raised concerns about the low level of stock market volatility, especially given the low level of interest rates, which many associate with investors’ increased willingness to take on risk (or reach for yield). Based on similarities to the low volatility environment before the financial crisis, some suggest that investor complacency may contribute to a major correction in equity markets when volatility returns to a “normal” level.  One argument is based on the simple idea that stock market volatility will revert to its historical mean, with equity valuations dropping while volatility “corrects.” In the past, increases in volatility have been negatively correlated with stock market returns. As the chart below shows, if the VIX were to return to a “normal” level closer to its average of around 20 percent since 1990, the S&P 500 index might be expected to decline by 5-10 percent.  The Low Volatility Puzzle: Are Investors Complacent? While this sounds like a potential warning sign, there are two limitations to the simple mean reversion argument. First, the assumed mean for the VIX is based on a statistical analysis of historical patterns. If the post-crisis regime is different, the “correct” level for the VIX may have changed. Second, even if the mean remains the same, the speed of mean reversion is a key aspect of the risk profile. An increase in the VIX from 10 percent to 20 percent has different implications if the move happens over one week versus one year.  In contrast to mean reversion, the macro-finance literature has raised a more nuanced argument for why low volatility may lead to a buildup of risks to financial stability. In Brunnermeier and Sannikov (2014) and Adrian and Shin (2013) , decreased volatility during business cycle expansions may lead to lower value-at-risk constraints for investors as well as lower margin and collateral requirements. If investors respond by increasing leverage, small shocks to asset prices may suddenly make constraints bind, which can force investors to sell assets, raise volatility, and tighten constraints further. This feedback loop creates risk endogenously, meaning that low volatility in itself can be a catalyst for high future volatility.  Alternative View: Yesterday Was Abnormal and Current Stock Market Volatility Is Not a Concern 
To assess the low level of volatility further, it is useful to think about the fundamental sources of stock market volatility that determine its level of mean reversion. According to asset pricing theory, stock prices are equal to the expected value of discounted dividends. As a result, stock price volatility results from either dividend volatility or time-variation in the discount rate used to compute the net present value of dividends.  As discussed in Robert Shiller’s Nobel Prize lecture , the original puzzle in financial economics was why stock prices are so volatile relative to dividends. According to the Gordon growth formula, stock prices and dividends should have the same volatility. In the data, however, stock prices are significantly more volatile than dividends. Since the 1950s, stock prices have exhibited 16 percent annualized volatility. That is almost 10 percentage points higher than the “fundamental” volatility of dividends, which has been closer to 7 percent (for example, see Shiller’s annual data).  Shiller interpreted these results as evidence that stock prices were inefficient, with investors potentially succumbing to animal spirits, or “waves of optimism and pessimism,” to explain the large variation in stock prices (see John Cochrane’s discussion of this view in a Grumpy Economist blog post) . Importantly, however, Shiller’s analysis assumed a constant discount rate for computing net present values. Subsequent work provided evidence against this assumption. Time-varying discount rates are now a standard feature of asset pricing models that can explain the excess volatility of stock prices relative to dividends (see Discount Rates by Cochrane or Monika Piazzesi’s summary of related asset pricing research).  As shown in the previous chart, today’s realized volatility is about 6-7 percent. This level is what one would have originally predicted using the Gordon growth formula, suggesting that the low volatility puzzle is perhaps less puzzling than originally thought. Alternatively, if one subscribes to the more recent asset pricing theories, it appears that current volatility is either abnormally low or that discount rate variation has somehow been dampened, leading us back to concerns about investor complacency.  Evidence on Complacency from the Volatility Risk Premium 
Taking the level of realized volatility as given, one way to gauge investor complacency is through the expected returns that investors demand for selling options. To that end, we decompose the VIX into a one-month volatility forecast and a one-month volatility risk premium using an updated model from Van Tassel and Vogt 2016 (strictly speaking, we estimate the variance risk premium, which is the expected return for receiving the fixed leg in variance swaps over a one-month horizon). The volatility risk premium, plotted in the chart below, represents the time-varying expected return from selling insurance on stock market volatility. The expected returns are positive, reflecting the fact that investors demand compensation for an investment that suffers losses in bad economic states of the world. As noted above, stock prices tend to go down when volatility goes up.  If investors are compressing implied volatility by selling options, we should see this reflected in the estimated volatility risk premium. In the model, we estimate the volatility risk premium to be 0.64 percent as of September 2017. This estimate is below the 2 percent historical average of the volatility risk premium. It also contrasts with the 1 percent upper bound for the volatility risk premium that one can obtain by squaring the VIX, given the VIX’s current level of about 10 percent. Beyond the current level, we can also observe that the volatility risk premium has been below its long-run mean and has exhibited less volatility since around 2012. While low realized volatility may be consistent with the prediction from the Gordon growth model, the volatility risk premium appears to be low both in absolute terms and relative to its historical norm, which may suggest complacency.  The Low Volatility Puzzle: Are Investors Complacent? Are Investors Complacent? The Evidence Is Mixed 
While the low volatility risk premium provides some evidence of complacency, we find the concerns based on the VIX mean reversion argument to be limited. First, it is unclear whether the long-run mean of the VIX is changing over time, especially in the context of the excess volatility puzzle documented by Shiller. Second, while the current level of the VIX is low, it is difficult to pinpoint the horizon over which the VIX may increase (for example, see the large trade in VIX options this July whose payoff expired out of the money in October). An open question is whether investors understand that volatility may be higher in the future. We explore this issue in our next post.   fed ny research

Looking at the VIX data from FRED, covering the period from Jan 1990 to Oct 2017, and taking the price as the random variable. The critical assumption we make is that VIX price follows a Gaussian Law with mean =19.43602, and sd =7.865011, then the probability that ViX is greater than 30 follows. Another critical assumption here is that of Normal behaviour, i.e this scenario is one out of billions and it is only valid if markets are behaving normally, this assumption will break down under excessive market stress.
keep in mind that out of the past 7000 trading days, the VIX was above 30,  580 trading days, which also gives a frequency of approx 8.286%. using a different model that takes into account the behaviour in the tail, and gives  a higher probability of occurring is better than the Gaussian assumption.

I am lowering my expected probability to 3% from 5% to account for further passage of time. I am confident that the VIX would rise above 30 if the S&P 500 falls 20% or more from its year-to-date high by the end of 2017. The median answer on GJO'S "Will the S&P 500 fall 20% or more in 2017?" question is 5%, while the median answer on GJO'S "Before 1 January 2018, will the Chicago Board Options Exchange's CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) exceed 30?" question is 10%.

Base rate calculation: Six out of the last five years. Only 143 days out of 365 until forecast horizon. 1.2*0.3917808219178082 = 0.47. So 47% chance is the base rate.  I'm going with this, with reductions for passage of time until reaching 0% on Dec. 31, presuming the VIX doesn't surpass 30 before then. During this process, if I were to observe increasing volatility or news that might portend increasing VIX, I will adjust the probability upward. As for adjusting downward, I see little likelihood of the kind of calm news that could ensure this. We are well overdue for a Great Recession, price to earnings in the S&P companies has become ridiculous, and I personally have been rebalancing my nest egg more toward bonds. I see that the consensus is well below my forecast, and I can understand why. The CBOE VIX has been remarkably stable over the last year. However, see Herbert Stein's Law: "If something cannot go on forever, it will stop,"
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
The VIX will go higher, but the question is whether it will exceed 30. I am betting a cautious "no" for now.

My forecast is based on a Poisson distribution. The forecast seems to be relatively high compared to others due to the reason that I seem to have found more instances where the VIX exceeded 30. To calibrate it I downloaded the daily OHLC Data from http://www.cboe.com/products/vix-index-volatility/vix-options-and-futures/vix-index/vix-historical-data and found that there were 9 instances since August 31, 2012 (arbitrary date, found 5 years a reasonable time frame) where the CBOE VIX exceeded 30 (used a simple Excel formula to count the number of times where the intraday high exceeded 30). 
(Note that it would be incorrect to simply use (9*4)/(5*12) as the probability of it happening during four months. To show this we assume that this would be the correct way of estimating the probability. In this case, it should work for larger time frames as well and if we use 7 months instead of 4 and we would get a 105% probability, which is impossible and contradicts our assumption. Therefore this approach can't be correct.) I have set the parameter (based on 4 months intervals, because there are approximately 4 months left until Jan 1st) lambda=(9*4)/(5*12)=0.6. Let k denote the number of times the VIX exceeds 30. I am interested in the following probability (everything is based on 4 months):
P(VIX exceeds 30 at least one time) = 1 - P(VIX never exceeds 30) is equivalent to
P(k>=1) = 1 - P(k=0) = 1- exp(-0.6)*0.6^0/(0!) = 1- exp(-0.6) = 0.451 = 45%.
In the last 5 years, ​VIX exceeded 30 once. -> 20%. Multiply by 4/12 (6.7%) to adjust for the shorter timeframe. Adjusted upward because of geopolitical tensions in North Korea

What is VIX really? Since it is calculated using out-of-money puts/calls of SPX, it is the collective judgement of investors. The VIX is currently under 16 (the level of VIX when there was political risks such as Charlotteville event), that means investors see that the annualized lost/gain within the next 30 days is about 16% max. Yes, the VIX is used as a proxy of "fear gauge" (since it is calculated from the out of money puts/calls of SPX, and because downward volatility is always greater than upward volatility). Yes, it is non-linear (because options are non-linear). Yes, the forecast by the market of "annualized gain/loss of 16% for the next 30 days" is just an average, there could be larger movements. But this is in the heart of good judgement system: I am using the wisdom of the crowd (especially those professional money managers, since they are the one using SPX options to hedge their porfolios, with their money or reputation on the line). So, I would be ready to revise my forecast when VIX cross over 20. At that level, the market signals an elevated anxiety. Coming from another angle: the historical data of VIX, especially the proability of VIX to be 30 within 5 days of a given level of VIX. From that data, I could see that the probability of VIX = 30 given current VIX of 16 is pretty much 0. And these are through much more uncertain political climate. The probability becomes non-null when VIX=20. Therefore, I'll re-evaluate my prediction when VIX cross over 20. And lastly, we are asked to forecast a Black Swan event (VIX over 30 us quite infrequent). Black Swan exists, probability is non-null and could be larger than a typical normal curve suggest. The stock market valuation is at historic high, and there is some chance that VIX > 30. But we can't predict Black Swan. For something you can't predict, it is logical to put its probability to 0 (any other number means you are predicting a Black Swan event).
With rising tension in geopolitics, and the financial world retaining low interest rates, near term economic prosperity remains fragile

The VIX hit 17.28 today, which while not the 52-week high, nor is the only time the market has hit 15 in the past few months, still feels like the probability of going higher is up. This is both given the news and reactions from my local population. Adding to this, the VVIX has reached a multi-year high. While not a perfect tool, it feels like it has some predictive powers.
I have so far been using a time series approach as a base for the VIX. Only 12 times since 1991 has the VIX been over 30, without going over 30 in the prior six months, so this is rare event in general. Today I extended this analysis by testing how many times has the VIX reached 30 in the six months after reaching 15, and not exceeding 30 in the six months prior. This is still a less than 1% occurrence. This is not a perfect analysis, but something to hang my hat on.
Raising my forecast to 5%, with regards to the VVIX moving up with the VIX. (I moved my forecast up to 7% yesterday in reaction to the news, but now that I have had more time to think about it, I am going to settle at 5% for now). There are a number of secular  trends weighing on the VIX.

I have an interest in financial markets and options markets. In the past 8 years, there have been 4 in which the VIX has gone above  30, however it has ocurred in 2 of the past 5. From 2010-2016, the maximum volatility from August to December has been, 28.92, 48, 21, 21.34, 31.06, 53.29, and 23.01. It should be noted that this we are in an historically low volatility environment, but that there are many reasons in which a short spike in volatility can occur that has little to do with economics. A flash crash or geopolitical conflicts being two reasons. I think that current environment has lower than a baseline risk which I would put somewhere between 30-40%.

The CBOE Volatility Index has never closed above 30 in the past five years.  The highest closing price in the past five years was 28 in August of 2015.  During that peak period of time, the Great Recession had officially ended and institutional buyers were regaining confidence in a steady upward trend of the S & P 500.   As far as I can tell, from the financial product's inception in 2004, a daily spike above 30 has never taken place.  Today's closing price is 11.54  with a strong and upwardly trending S & P 500.  I cannot foresee a situation in the next 6 months that would triple the value of VIX shares.

The Vix gauge of implied US equity volatility, popularly described as Wall Street’s fear gauge, remains low, at just 11.2 at the end of trading on Friday. But the September futures contract linked to the index has gingerly risen from its low in mid-June of just under 13 to 14.1, and the Vix “curve” made up of longer-dated volatility futures has steepened, indicating that traders think there could be more turbulence in the second half of 2017." That's quite a bit. Increased computing power, algorithmic trading that is less susceptible to emotion, more warnings by banks and other factors have caused the CBOE VIX to spike less intensely. The near certainty that the White House can't get anything meaningful done is a strong case for an economic status quo domestically (i.e. taxes, healthcare, major legislation). On the other hand, the geopolitical events that could trigger such uncertainty are typically relegated to the executive branch. If Trump wittingly colluded with Russia during the election, the extent of its electoral impact in 2016 is questionable; what's slightly more concerning is the theater (both drama and proxied military posturing) that the U.S. and Russia are engaging in to distance themselves from such allegations. Independent of direct U.S. foreign policy, the probability of events that could cause a CBOE spike of that magnitude probably looks like a fat-tailed distribution, with lots of risky, low probability events. So plausible and risky, but not too probable. I have yet to look at statistics, so this is purely based on a thought exercise and I'll likely revise.

In the past 10 years, we have three times the VIX gets higher than 30: in 2008-2009, 2010 and 2011. These are times of great uncertainty, financial crisis, Greece default, etc. The VIX also hover around 20. Now, starting below 15, the VIX needs to double, or there must be quite a large movement (30% drop for example) of the stock market. While there are cautious warnings about complacency and over-confidence, the risk of quite large a drop is much less. Worse case, Trump-trade will revert itself to the end of Obama environment (and that assumes the Democrats succeed to totally halt Trump's pro-business pro-market policies). In such scenario, VIX would surpass 20 but would still way below 30.
I will revise the odds when VIX hit 20. As long as VIX stays below 20, the chance for it to go to 30 is nil.

The market appeared to have settled after Trumps election to a very low rate of expected volatility. Given that it is an expectation of the near term volatility, there is no real ability to see a stable six months from this current number. Instead we need to look at what events might create a high degree of price variation with a 30 day time frame. The most likely appears to be "Truvent" (Trump Event). Right now the most likely drivers of uncertainty are investigations that will not be concluded for months yet. Once the conclusion looks to be on the horizon the index will start to raise its head and pay attention. Given the severity of the possible outcomes by comparison to other events that have pushed in the index above 30, the probability of an intra day move above this limit is likely.

30 on VIX is a great objective test of whether the market is having a mild panic, and for that I would attribute a 33% chance by end year.  However I am also aware that more money is now managed in a passive or quantitative (eg risk targetted) approach, than than through fundamental analysis of earning prospects or valuation.  Put it this way, active investors usually find some money from the back of the sofa following a market sell off, passive investors by definition do not.  Momentum investors such as CTAs, will sell, and push volatility higher in adverse conditions. Risk targeting investors likewise.  In my mind the industry that has sprouted around volatility is similar to structured credit in the mid 2000's, which took a couple of years for inventory to clear.  I suspect volatility might be faster to unwind, but most importantly, any event that pushes it to 20, is likely to see technical pressure blow it to 40.  Which leads me to double the probability to 66%.
